subject: Cybersecurity
title: Network Forensics: Reconstructing the Crime Scene
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Network Forensics: Reconstructing the Crime Scene.

hook.text: Every packet that crosses your network is a potential clue. After a breach, forensic analysts reconstruct what happened.

buildup.text: Network forensics captures and analyzes traffic to identify attack patterns, data theft, and attacker infrastructure.

discovery.text: Full packet capture records everything. Metadata capture records connection details. Both help reconstruct.

twist.text: Most organizations don't retain enough network data for forensics. When breached, the evidence is already gone.

climax.text: Network forensics is like a security camera for your network â€” but only useful if it was recording when the breach happened.

punchline.text: The breach happened. The evidence wasn't recorded.

quiz.question: What is the biggest challenge in network forensics?
options: Most organizations don't retain enough network data, so evidence is lost before investigation
